articles.headline: Former KBR Executive Pleads Guilty to Bribery
articles.snippet: A former chief executive of the former Halliburton subsidiary pleaded guilty to federal bribery and kickback charges in connection with work done in Nigeria from 1995 to 2004.
articles.abstract: A former chief executive of the former Halliburton subsidiary pleaded guilty to federal bribery and kickback charges in connection with work done in Nigeria from 1995 to 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  Albert J. Stanley, a former executive with a Halliburton subsidiary, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to charges that he conspired to pay $182 million in bribes to Nigerian officials in return for contracts to build a $6 billion liquefied natural gas complex.

articles.headline: Assessing the Value of Small Wind Turbines
articles.snippet: Interest for wind turbines small enough to mount on a roof is spreading from coast to coast, even though their installation is hardly ever recouped in electricity savings.
articles.abstract: Interest for wind turbines small enough to mount on a roof is spreading from coast to coast, even though their installation is hardly ever recouped in electricity savings.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With the California blackouts of 2001 still a painful memory, Chris Beaudoin wants to generate some of his own electricity. He marveled the other day at how close he is to that goal, gazing at two new wind turbines atop his garage roof. They will soon be hooked to the power grid.

articles.headline: On Internet, You’ve Got (Paper) Mail
articles.snippet: Exploring the joys and woes of an online mailbox whose address never changes.
articles.abstract: Exploring the joys and woes of an online mailbox whose address never changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Years ago, I had a computer student I’ll call Mrs. K, whose specialty was negativity. Her ability to find fault with absolutely anything amounted to a gift.

articles.headline: In Reversal, New Orleans Lets Residents Return
articles.snippet: As people began trickling back to the city, utility officials gave no word on when electricity would be restored.
articles.abstract: As people began trickling back to the city, utility officials gave no word on when electricity would be restored.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  With thousands of residents stacked up at entrances to this city, impatient to return home after evacuating for Hurricane Gustav, Mayor C. Ray Nagin shifted course Wednesday morning and ordered an immediate lifting of barriers blocking their entry.

articles.headline: Investments Are Faltering in Chrysler and GMAC
articles.snippet: The investment fund Cerberus Capital Management is racing to salvage multibillion-dollar investments in the automaker Chrysler and GMAC, the financing arm of General Motors.
articles.abstract: The investment fund Cerberus Capital Management is racing to salvage multibillion-dollar investments in the automaker Chrysler and GMAC, the financing arm of General Motors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stephen A. Feinberg, one of the country’s most powerful  and secretive  financiers, hoped to make a fortune out of the detritus of the American auto industry. Instead, he seems to be losing one.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Serving a Cause and a Desire to Succeed
articles.snippet: John McCain stands at the pinnacle of a career defined by a singular ambivalence about his own ambition.
articles.abstract: John McCain stands at the pinnacle of a career defined by a singular ambivalence about his own ambition.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL  Senator John McCain’s Republican primary campaign looked all but hopeless. He had risked the wrath of his party to push for an immigration overhaul and now, just months before the Iowa caucuses, his grand compromise was falling apart on the Senate floor as well.
articles.byline: By Mark Leibovich and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: The Unusual Challenges Palin Faced in Alaska
articles.snippet: Like other distinctions about the biggest, wildest, coldest state, being governor there is just flat different.
articles.abstract: Like other distinctions about the biggest, wildest, coldest state, being governor there is just flat different.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — Like so many other distinctions about Alaska — the biggest, wildest, coldest state not even half a century removed from its territorial days — being governor here is just flat different.

articles.headline: Connecticut Wonders, Again, About Its Senator
articles.snippet: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman’s speech to the Republican National Convention got dissected left and right.
articles.abstract: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman’s speech to the Republican National Convention got dissected left and right.

articles.headline: Palin Assails Critics and Electrifies Party
articles.snippet: Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska sought to wrest back the narrative of her life as she introduced herself to a roaring crowd at the Republican National Convention.
articles.abstract: Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska sought to wrest back the narrative of her life as she introduced herself to a roaring crowd at the Republican National Convention.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska introduced herself to America before a roaring crowd at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday night as “just your average hockey mom” who was as qualified as the Democratic nominee, Senator Barack Obama, to be president of the United States.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Michael Cooper
